questions.text: Identify the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The above image shows giardia lamblia.
  • Cysts are resistant forms and are responsible for transmission of giardiasis. Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces (diagnostic stages). The cysts are hardy and can survive several months in cold water.
  • Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water, food, or by the fecal-oral route (hands or fomites).
  • In the small intestine, excystation releases trophozoites (each cyst produces two trophozoites).
  • Trophozoites multiply by longitudinal binary fission, remaining in the lumen of the proximal small bowel where they can be free or attached to the mucosa by a ventral sucking disk.
  • The cysts are infectious when passed in the stool or shortly afterward, person-to-person transmission is possible.
  • Giardia lamblia exists in:
    • Infective form - Quadrinucleate cyst
    • Tennis racket shaped trophozoite is actively motile with central axostyle with pair of nuclei
    • Oval shaped cyst denoted with cyst wall

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba dispar: Morphologically similar to E. histolytica but is non-pathogenic and does not cause invasive disease.

 

Option C. Balantidium coli: The only ciliate known to infect humans, characterized by large size and the presence of cilia.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebiasis, with cysts and trophozoites distinguishable by their size and internal structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia in its cyst form, is the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated water, food, or fecal-oral route.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text: The spinal trigeminal nucleus forms the second-order neuron of which of the following sensations? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus is located in the medulla and functions as a relay center, particularly for pain and temperature sensations from the face. It processes these sensations and transmits the information to higher brain centers for interpretation. The second-order neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus specifically relay pain and temperature information, making it a critical component in the sensory pathway for these modalities.

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus does not act as a relay center for other sensations like touch, two-point discrimination, or conscious proprioception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Touch: The sensation of touch is primarily processed through other pathways, such as the dorsal columns and the main sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, rather than the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option C. Two-point discrimination: This sensation is typically processed by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option D. Conscious proprioception: Conscious proprioception is also processed via the dorsal columns, particularly through the cuneate and gracile nuclei, and not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus in the medulla serves as the second-order neuron relay center specifically for pain and temperature sensations from the face.

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was found in India? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. This disease is zoonotic, meaning it originates from animals, with ticks acting as vectors.

 

Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF):

 

  • Causative Agent: Nairovirus species.
  • Transmission: The primary vectors are ticks, specifically those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Outbreaks: The disease can spread through person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings, where it poses a significant risk to healthcare workers and patients.
  • Symptoms: Include fever, muscle pain, dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes, and photophobia. Severe cases can lead to extensive hemorrhaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another severe viral hemorrhagic fever but has not been reported in India. It primarily affects regions in Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral hemorrhagic disease endemic to Africa and South America. It has not been reported in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus causes a severe hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola. It has also not been reported in India and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the viral hemorrhagic fever that has been confirmed in India. It is caused by the Nairovirus species and is transmitted by ticks, with potential for person-to-person transmission, especially in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

 

Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

 

The Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV), belongs to the family of DNA viruses Herpeseviridae. It causes Kaposi sarcoma (a vascular malignancy) and B cell lymphoproliferative diseases such as primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with double vision, particularly noticeable when descending stairs. On examination, there is difficulty with downward gaze when the eye is adducted. A detailed anatomical study identifies the nerve responsible for this condition, which is unique as it emerges from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem at the level of the inferior colliculus. Identify the cranial nerve passing through the marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

 

The nerve passing through the marked structure is the trochlear nerve (CN IV). It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brainstem, specifically from the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus.

 

Origin: The trochlear nerve originates from the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei.

 

Course: It emerges from the dorsal brainstem and has the longest intracranial course among cranial nerves.

 

Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates the superior oblique muscle, which primarily intorts (rotates inward), depresses, and abducts the eyeball.

 

Clinical Relevance: Patients with trochlear nerve palsy often present with difficulty looking downward, particularly in the adducted position, leading to issues such as double vision when reading or descending stairs.

 

Muscle Actions Table Reference:

 

Superior Oblique Muscle:

 

Primary Action: Intorsion.

 

Secondary Action: Depression, particularly when the eye is adducted.

 

Tertiary Action: Abduction.

 

These actions are crucial for coordinated eye movements, particularly when looking downward and medially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve (CN III): Originates from the ventral midbrain and controls several extraocular muscles but does not emerge dorsally.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (CN VI): Emerges from the pons and controls lateral eye movement via the lateral rectus muscle, not from the dorsal brainstem.

 

Option D. Optic nerve (CN II): This nerve is associated with vision and is purely sensory; it does not emerge from the brainstem or control eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal aspect of the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. It innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for specific eye movements such as intorsion, depression, and abduction, crucial for tasks like reading and navigating stairs. Understanding these anatomical and functional details helps diagnose trochlear nerve palsy, characterized by difficulties in downward gaze and double vision.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rроB

 

GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool widely used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin. It identifies mutations in the rpoB gene, which encodes the beta subunit of RNA polymerase. These mutations are responsible for rifampicin resistance, a critical marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

rpoB: The target gene for rifampicin resistance detection by GeneXpert. Mutations here confer rifampicin resistance

 

WHO strongly recommends Xpert assay for the diagnosis of TB and multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB in patients with HIV infection (WHO 2013).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. inhA: The inhA gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and ethionamide. However, GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option C. katG: The katG gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid, another key TB drug. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option D. pncA: The pncA gene is associated with resistance to pyrazinamide. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gene(s) involved in anti-tuberculosis drug resistance –

choices.text: More common in females
Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deep seated pain

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe, electric shock-like or stabbing pain that is typically superficial and localized to the face. It most often affects the V2 (maxillary) and V3 (mandibular) divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia is not deep-seated but rather feels as if it is on the surface of the face, which makes option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females: This is true. Trigeminal neuralgia is generally more common in females than in males.

 

Option B. Pain along V2 and V3 division of the trigeminal nerve: This is also true. While trigeminal neuralgia can affect any of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve, the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches are more commonly affected than the ophthalmic (V1) branch.

 

Option D. No objective signs of sensory loss: This is correct. Trigeminal neuralgia typically does not show any objective signs of sensory loss or neurological deficit on examination, which can make diagnosis challenging.

 

Educational Objective:


Trigeminal neuralgia is marked by sharp, superficial pain that may affect the V2 and V3 divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is important to recognize that the pain is superficial and not deep-seated. This condition more commonly affects females and presents without objective sensory loss.

 

Reference - Harrison/Trigeminal neuralgia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the nutritional targets of Mid-Day Meal Program, as per the Indian government guidelines? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1/2 protein and 1/3 calorie requirements

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
    • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
    • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
    • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
    • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
    • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal -

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST.
  2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
  3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas.
  4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 Only

 

ERBB2, also known as HER2, is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Overexpression of HER2 is strongly associated with breast carcinomas, specifically HER2-positive breast cancers. HER2 is a significant marker in breast cancer, as its overexpression or amplification can lead to more aggressive tumor growth and is a target for specific therapies like trastuzumab.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors): This statement is incorrect. KIT, also known as CD117, is commonly overexpressed in GISTs. The detection of KIT is often used diagnostically to confirm GIST.

 

2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma: This statement is incorrect. KRAS mutations are more commonly associated with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), particularly adenocarcinoma of the lung, as well as colorectal and pancreatic cancers. 

 

4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers: This statement is incorrect. PDGFR-β (Platelet-derived growth factor receptor beta) is generally overexpressed in gliomas and leukemias, rather than being suppressed in colorectal cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ERBB2 encodes for HER2, which is involved in Breast carcinoma. ERBB1 encodes for EGFR, which is involved in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • Genes involved in GIST are → DOG1 > CD117 (cKIT) > CD34
  • KRAS mutations are cause of Lung, colorectal and pancreatic carcinoma. Gain of function mutation is seen in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • PDGFR-β over-expression is seen in Glioma and Leukemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with epilepsy was started on phenytoin and valproate. Four weeks later, she developed a diffuse rash that resolved after discontinuing both drugs. If she is re-challenged with phenytoin and valproate, how soon will the rash reappear? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1 day

 

Hypersensitivity to anti-epileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, is a Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (Steven-Johnson Syndrome), which typically develops within 3 weeks to 3 months after initiating treatment. When the drug is re-challenged, the mediators are already pre-formed and are released much quicker, causing the rash to reappear on the day of starting the treatment.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 1 week: This timeframe is incorrect as the rash reappears much quicker than one week upon re-challenge.

 

Option C. 2 weeks: The rash reappears sooner than two weeks when re-challenged due to pre-formed mediators.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeframe is too long, as the rash reappears on the day of starting the treatment upon re-challenge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient is re-challenged with phenytoin, the hypersensitivity reaction and associated rash reappear much quicker, typically on the day of starting the treatment, due to pre-formed mediators.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate


Calcium oxalate crystals are typically bipyramidal or envelope-shaped. These crystals are common in various conditions, including hyperoxaluria and ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Calcium phosphate:  crystals form asymmetric rosettes.

 

Option C. Uric acid:  crystals are rhomboid forming rosettes, polychromatophilic in Polarized Microscope.

 

Option D. Cystine:  crystals are hexagonal, and one of the hardest crystals.

 

Note - Monohydrate crystal – dumbbell shaped

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate crystals are bipyramidal or envelope-shaped.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BTK

 

BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).

 

Other Options:

 

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:

 

Option B. JAK3: Mutations in the JAK3 gene are associated with an autosomal recessive form of SCID. JAK3 is essential for the signaling pathways of multiple cytokine receptors, including IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15, and IL-21, which are crucial for lymphocyte development and function.

 

Option C.  RAG1: The RAG1 gene, along with RAG2, is crucial for V(D)J recombination, which is necessary for the generation of diverse antigen receptors on B cells and T cells. Mutations in RAG1 can lead to SCID due to the inability to produce functional B and T cells.

 

Option D. IL-7Ra: The IL-7 receptor alpha chain (IL-7Ra) is important for T-cell development. Mutations in IL-7Ra can lead to a T- B+ NK+ form of SCID, where T cells are absent or non-functional, but B cells and natural killer cells are present.

 

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:

 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by mutations in several different genes

 

  • JAK3
  • RAG1
  • IL-7Ra

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 438-439

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which requires routine coagulation profile monitoring. The standard test used for monitoring Lepirudin is the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). In cath labs, when administering in high doses need to be monitor with ACT (Activated Clotting Time) rather than aPTT.

 

This is necessary to ensure the correct therapeutic range is maintained and to avoid complications such as bleeding.

 

Note - There are four parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors: lepirudin, hirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It has a predictable anticoagulant effect, and routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required under standard clinical circumstances. In special situations, monitoring can be done using anti-factor Xa levels.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux, like Enoxaparin, does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. In specific clinical scenarios, anti-factor Xa levels may be measured.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is classified under direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Routine coagulation monitoring is not required due to its reliable and predictable effects. However, if monitoring is needed, aPTT can be used, though more specific tests like the dilute thrombin time (dTT) or the ecarin clotting time (ECT) are preferred for accurate measurement.

 

Note - There are four DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants): Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor), Apixaban, Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban (all 3 are factor Xa inhibitor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: Which procedure amongst the following has the highest probability of ureteric injury? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the radical nature of the procedure. Wertheim's hysterectomy, also known as radical hysterectomy, involves extensive dissection and removal of not only the uterus but also the surrounding tissues, including the parametria and the upper part of the vagina. This extensive dissection increases the risk of ureteric injury.

 

However, it's important to note that while Wertheim's hysterectomy carries a higher individual risk for ureteric injury due to its radical nature, the most common cause of ureteric injury overall is abdominal hysterectomy, simply because it is the most commonly performed type of hysterectomy.

 

The overall incidence of ureteric injury in all pelvic operations is about 0.5-1%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal hysterectomy: Although it is the most common cause of ureteric injury due to its high frequency, the individual risk per procedure is lower than that of Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: This procedure has a lower risk of ureteric injury compared to abdominal and Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Anterior colporrhaphy: This procedure, which is used to repair the anterior vaginal wall, has a much lower risk of ureteric injury compared to hysterectomy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the extensive dissection involved in the procedure.

 

The risk of ureteric injury is highest with a radical hysterectomy followed laparoscopic or robotic hysterectomy followed by abdominal hysterectomy and least risk is with vaginal hysterectomy

 

Ref: TeLinde’s Operative gynecology 12th edition

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with acute myeloid leukemia undergoing chemotherapy requires a blood transfusion. Given the patient’s immunocompromised state, the medical team decides to transfuse irradiated red blood cells (RBCs). This special preparation is used to prevent a specific, serious transfusion-related complication that can occur in vulnerable patients. Which of the following conditions is effectively prevented by transfusing irradiated RBCs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD)

 

Transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD) is a rare but severe complication of blood transfusion in which donor T lymphocytes attack the recipient’s tissues. This complication is especially dangerous in immunocompromised patients or those receiving transfusions from close relatives. Irradiation of blood products effectively inactivates these T lymphocytes, preventing their proliferation and the subsequent development of TA-GVHD. This preventive measure is crucial in high-risk groups such as bone marrow transplant recipients, individuals with congenital immunodeficiencies, and patients receiving blood from family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is an immune-mediated reaction involving donor antibodies and recipient leukocytes, leading to acute lung injury. It is not prevented by blood irradiation.

 

Option B. Febrile transfusion reaction: This reaction is typically caused by cytokines and leukocytes in the transfused blood. It is managed with leukoreduction but is not prevented by irradiation.

 

Option D. Hemolytic reaction: This occurs due to blood type incompatibility and is not related to T lymphocyte activity; irradiation does not prevent this complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) is an important intervention to prevent transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD) by inactivating donor T lymphocytes. This practice is critical in managing patients at high risk, such as those who are immunocompromised, to avoid this severe and potentially fatal condition.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

choices.text: Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later
Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later

questions.text: What is the correct order of using eye drops and eye ointment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later

 

To ensure proper absorption of medication, it is recommended to use eye drops before ointment. Eye drops have a thinner consistency and are absorbed more quickly, whereas ointments are thicker and need more time for absorption. Therefore, eye drops should be used first, followed by ointment after a gap of 15 minutes, especially when using both at the same time. Ointments are typically used at bedtime due to their prolonged absorption time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later and D. Ointment first, then eye drops immediately: Incorrect because the ointment could prevent the eye drops from being absorbed properly by creating a barrier.

 

Note - Ointments are generally used last, particularly at bedtime, to maintain medication contact with the eye surface for an extended period, aiding in treatment effectiveness, especially in conditions requiring continuous exposure to the medication.

 

Option C. Eye drops first, then ointment immediately: Incorrect as applying ointment immediately after drops could interfere with the absorption of the drops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always use eye drops before eye ointment when both forms of medication are prescribed. Allowing a gap of 15 minutes between applying drops and ointment ensures maximum effectiveness of both medications without interference in absorption.

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of gun injuries

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body

 

Battered child syndrome is defined as the collection of injuries sustained by a child as a result of repeated mistreatment or beating. If a child's injuries indicate intentional trauma or appear to be more severe than could reasonably be expected to result from an accident, battered child syndrome should be suspected.

 

Skin lesions and bruises of different ages (from young to old) are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

 

Skeletal survey helps in identifying bone injuries in Battered Baby syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly: False: While children do fall frequently, the pattern and severity of injuries in battered child syndrome are inconsistent with typical childhood falls and accidents.

 

Option C. Stab wounds are obvious: False: Stab wounds are not a common feature of battered child syndrome. The syndrome primarily involves bruises, fractures, and other signs of physical abuse.

 

Option D. The syndrome is a result of gun injuries: False: Battered child syndrome is not characterized by gun injuries. It involves repeated physical abuse, leading to various types of trauma, particularly bruises and fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battered child syndrome is characterized by the presence of skin lesions and bruises of different ages, indicating repeated and ongoing physical abuse.

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: What is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileocecal junction

 

The ileocecal junction is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis. This area, which includes the terminal ileum and the beginning of the large intestine (cecum), is particularly susceptible to infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The lymphoid tissue in this region provides a favorable environment for the bacteria to proliferate.

 

Abdominal tuberculosis can present in two primary forms: hypertrophic and ulcerative. The hypertrophic form involves thickening of the intestinal wall, while the ulcerative form leads to the formation of ulcers. Clinically, differentiating abdominal tuberculosis from Crohn's disease can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms and similar radiologic findings. In some cases, empirical anti-tubercular therapy (ATP) may be initiated, with subsequent monitoring for clinical improvement to help distinguish between the two conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectum: The rectum is not a common site for abdominal tuberculosis. Tuberculosis primarily affects the ileocecal region and less frequently involves other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Colon: While tuberculosis can affect the colon, it is not the most common site. The ileocecal junction is more frequently involved in abdominal tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Small intestine: Although the small intestine can be affected, the terminal ileum specifically, which is part of the ileocecal junction, is the most common site for tuberculosis within the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site of abdominal tuberculosis is the ileocecal junction, particularly near the terminal ileum. This region's lymphoid tissue creates a favorable environment for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to proliferate.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis:

 

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a type of Mullerian anomaly, which can be low, mid, or high and can be complete or incomplete.
  • It can present as primary amenorrhea with cyclical abdominal pain if complete.
  • The obstruction to blood flow caused by a transverse vaginal septum can lead to the accumulation of blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), which can subsequently cause retrograde menstruation and result in endometriosis.
  • The chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea in this patient are consistent with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubo-ovarian abscess: Tubo-ovarian abscess is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and a tender adnexal mass. It is not directly related to Mullerian anomalies like a transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option C. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that typically do not cause dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain related to menstrual obstruction. They are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option D. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and are seen in conditions like molar pregnancy and multiple gestations. They do not cause symptoms related to menstrual obstruction and are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with lytic lesions on the skull, skin rashes, and a history of frequent ear infections. The clinical presentation raises suspicion of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). A biopsy is performed, and the sample is analyzed under electron microscopy. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy that would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Birbeck granules

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by the abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are specialized dendritic cells normally involved in antigen presentation. On electron microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells is a pathognomonic finding. Birbeck granules have a distinctive tennis racket-like appearance due to their rod-shaped structure with a dilated terminal end. They contain the protein langerin (CD207), which plays a role in antigen processing.

 

 

Birbeck Granules: Rod-shaped structures with a dilated terminal end, resembling a tennis racket, seen in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells.

 

Diagnostic Importance: Their presence confirms the diagnosis of LCH, helping differentiate it from other histiocytic disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Auer rods : Found in myeloid blasts, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), but not associated with LCH.

 

Option C. Howell-Jolly bodies : Nuclear remnants seen in red blood cells, typically associated with splenic dysfunction, not relevant to LCH.

 

Option D. Psammoma bodies : Calcified structures seen in some tumors like meningiomas and papillary thyroid carcinoma, unrelated to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) and confirms the diagnosis. Recognizing these granules is essential in differentiating LCH from other conditions and guiding appropriate management.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.

 

Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

 

The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 page no 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

choices.text: Made of amino acids and sugars

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about proteoglycans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Holds less water

 

Proteoglycans are widely distributed complex molecules having glycosaminoglycans (GAG) and proteins. The GAGs containing repeating disaccharide units are covalently bound to the peptide chain to form proteoglycans. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Chondroitin sulfate It is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on. It is a glycosaminoglycan bound to a protein; hence it is a proteoglycan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carries Negative Charge: Proteoglycans carry negative charges due to the presence of sulfate and carboxyl groups on the GAG chains. These negatively charged groups attract positively charged ions and water molecules.

 

Option B. Chondroitin Sulfate is a Proteoglycan: Chondroitin sulfate is a type of GAG that, when attached to a core protein, forms a proteoglycan. It is widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, and skin.

 

Option C. Made of Amino Acids and Sugars: Proteoglycans are made up of a protein core (composed of amino acids) and one or more GAG chains (composed of sugars).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteoglycans are complex molecules made of amino acids and sugars, carrying negative charges and holding a significant amount of water due to their hydrophilic nature. Chondroitin sulfate, a type of GAG, forms proteoglycans when bound to a protein.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shock

 

Apoplexy refers to acute neurologic impairment due to a vascular compromise, usually hemorrhage, resulting in headache, visual disturbance and hormonal dysfunction due to infarction of pituitary gland.

 

Loss of glucocorticoids results in shock.

 

MRI is used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management:

 

  • If shock is present: IV glucocorticoids + IV fluids to maintain hemodynamic stability
  • If worsening neurologic symptoms (VA, GCS): Surgical decompression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension: Typically, hypertension is not a direct consequence of pituitary apoplexy. Instead, hypotension and shock are more common due to adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Unconsciousness: While not the most direct symptom, unconsciousness can occur if the apoplexy leads to significant increase in intracranial pressure or severe complications, but it's not as characteristic as shock.

 

Option D. Fatigue: Although patients may experience fatigue due to hormonal imbalances, it's not a primary or immediate concern in the acute setting of pituitary apoplexy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with hypoxemia. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a low PaO2, and further evaluation shows a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient.
