The patient denies any significant past medical history and shows no signs of lung disease on imaging. What is the most likely cause of his hypoxemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

A normal A-a oxygen gradient indicates that the transfer of oxygen from the alveoli to the arterial blood is functioning properly. Hypoxemia with a normal A-a gradient typically points to hypoventilation as the cause. Hypoventilation leads to a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) and an increase in carbon dioxide (PaCO2), but the oxygen transfer across the alveolar-capillary membrane remains normal, hence the normal A-a gradient.

 

Hypoventilation: Characterized by inadequate alveolar ventilation leading to decreased oxygen and increased carbon dioxide levels in the blood without affecting the A-a gradient.

 

Other causes of hypoxemia (Options A, B, D): Typically lead to an elevated A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer from the alveoli to the blood.

 

A-a Gradient in Other Conditions:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Embolism : Causes a V/Q mismatch and results in an increased A-a gradient.

 

Option B. V/Q Mismatch : Leads to impaired oxygenation with an increased A-a gradient.

 

Option D. Diffusion Impairment : Occurs in conditions like interstitial lung disease, where oxygen transfer is impaired, leading to an elevated A-a gradient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal A-a gradient in the context of hypoxemia suggests hypoventilation as the primary cause. Other causes of hypoxemia, such as shunting, V/Q mismatch, and diffusion impairment, usually result in an elevated A-a gradient. Recognizing the A-a gradient's role helps differentiate the underlying causes of hypoxemia effectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G4P1 A2 L1

 

Determining the Parity Index/ Obstetric Formula

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

The obstetric score here is G4P1A2L1.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2.

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

 

Syndrome Z also known as Metabolic Syndrome, is characterized by a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Syndrome involve the pressence of any three of the following five traits: 

 

Any 3/5 for diagnosis:

 

  1. Central Obesity: > 102cm (M),> 88 cm (F); [90(M), 80 cm (F) in Indians]: Only if questions specifically mention Indian population.
  2. BP > 130/85 mmHg
  3. FBS > 100 mg/dL/A1c
  4. Low HDL (in mg/dL): < 40 (F), < 50 cm(M)
  5. High TGL: > 150 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

choices.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mycoplasma pneumonia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Responds well to amoxiclav

 

Beta-lactam groups of drugs act by inhibiting the transpeptidation process of cell wall synthesis. Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall and hence is not affected by beta-lactams.

 

Azithromycin (DOC), Doxycycline, Fluoroquinolone (FQ) are effective in management of mycoplasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interstitial inflammation characterized by bilateral reticular infiltrates are seen on CXR.

 

Option C. IgM, IgG can be used in the diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

 

Option D. They show fried-egg appearance on cell free medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumonia does not respond to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a cell wall.

 

The preferred antibiotics for treating Mycoplasma pneumonia include macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), and fluoroquinolones for adults.

 

Reference - Resp Med/pneumonia, Harrison chap 188/5430

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucicarmine

 

Mucicarmine staining is specifically used to identify Cryptococcus, particularly useful in highlighting the thick polysaccharide capsule that is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast-like fungus that can cause serious infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The mucicarmine stain binds to the acidic polysaccharides of the fungal capsule and stains it a bright red, making it distinctly visible against a light blue background. This staining technique is especially valuable in histopathological diagnosis of cryptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giemsa stain: Primarily used for blood parasites and certain bacteria, it's not specific for fungal structures.

 

Option B. Ziehl-Nielsen stain: Used to identify acid-fast bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not fungi.

 

Option C. Gram staining: While it can stain a variety of bacteria, it is generally not effective for encapsulated fungi like Cryptococcus due to its poor affinity for fungal polysaccharide capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physiological

 

Physiological:

 

  • The discharge described is white with no pruritus and occurs mid-cycle (ovulatory) with a short duration, which is most likely physiological.
  • Increased physiological discharge is common during:
    • Puberty
    • Ovulation
    • Pregnancy
    • Occasionally during the premenstrual phase
  • It may be cervical or vaginal in origin. A speculum examination of the vagina can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical in origin, an excessive mucoid discharge will be visible at the external os.
  • Normal discharge appears clear or white, without any odor or itching, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis:

 

  • Typically presents with white, curdy discharge associated with intense itching and vulvar irritation.
  • The discharge often has a cottage cheese-like appearance.

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis:

 

  • Characterized by a thin, grayish-white, homogenous discharge with a fishy odor, especially noticeable after intercourse.
  • Itching is less common.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis:

 

  • Presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge with a strong odor.
  • Associated with vaginal itching, burning, and discomfort during intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, without odor or itching, and can occur at ovulation, puberty, pregnancy, or occasionally during the premenstrual phase.

 

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100 mcg

 

  • 100 mcg of carbetocin is used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • The use of carbetocin (100 mcg, IM/IV) is recommended for the prevention of PPH.
  • It is a long-acting synthetic analog of oxytocin which is stable at room temperature (unlike oxytocin which needs the cold chain to be maintained.
  • To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU - IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (100 ug - IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 g or 600 g, per-oral)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 ug - IM/IV)
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU,500g - IM)
  • Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent (drug of choice) for AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective:


The recommended dose of carbetocin for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage is 100 mcg, administered either IM or IV.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is undergoing an exploratory laparotomy due to severe abdominal pain and suspected internal organ involvement. During the surgery, the surgeon identifies a vertical slit-like structure behind the free right border of the lesser omentum, connecting two major compartments of the abdominal cavity. What is the superior border of this anatomical passage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Caudate lobe of the liver

 

The structure described in the question is the epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow), which is an anatomical passage within the abdominal cavity that connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of this foramen.

The caudate lobe is located on the posterior aspect of the liver, between the sulcus for the vena cava on the right and the fissure for the ligamentum venosum on the left. This lobe’s anatomical position plays a critical role during surgical exploration, as it defines the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallbladder: The gallbladder is not associated with the superior border of the epiploic foramen and is situated away from this structure.

 

Option B. Portal vein: The portal vein is positioned posteriorly to the epiploic foramen, forming the posterior boundary, but not the superior one.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava also forms part of the posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen but does not contribute to the superior border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is an important anatomical passage that connects the greater and lesser sacs of the abdomen. The superior border of the foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver, an important surgical landmark during abdominal procedures.

questions.text: A 33-week multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, proteinuria: 3+. The next step of management would be? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MgSO4 IV

 

In the scenario of imminent eclampsia, neuro-prophylaxis with Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) is recommended. Imminent eclampsia is characterized by symptoms such as severe headaches, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, and hyperreflexia, indicating that the woman is at high risk of developing seizures (eclampsia). MgSO4 is effective in preventing seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia and imminent eclampsia, as supported by the Magpie Trial, which is the largest comparative study demonstrating its efficacy.

 

The Magpie Trial (MgSO4 for Prevention of Eclampsia) showed that MgSO4 prophylaxis in women with severe pre-eclampsia effectively prevented the development of eclampsia, making it the standard of care for neuro-prophylaxis in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is an antenatal steroid used to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. It is administered in doses of 6 mg every 12 hours for a total of four doses. However, it is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option B. Betamethasone: Betamethasone, like dexamethasone, is also an antenatal steroid given to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. The typical regimen is 12 mg administered 24 hours apart for two doses. It is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option D. LSCS: The mode of delivery, whether vaginal or Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS), will depend on the status of the cervical os and other obstetric indications. LSCS is not a prophylactic measure for preventing eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is recommended for neuro-prophylaxis in women with severe or imminent eclampsia to prevent seizures.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1840

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile includes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NST and AFI

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes two key components: the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI). This abbreviated version of the BPP focuses on assessing fetal well-being through these two measures. The NST evaluates fetal heart rate patterns in response to fetal movements, while the AFI assesses the amount of amniotic fluid, which can indicate the health of the placenta and overall fetal condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NST and fetal tone: This combination is not the Modified BPP. While the NST is part of the Modified BPP, fetal tone is part of the complete Biophysical Profile but not included in the Modified BPP.

 

Option C. NST and breathing movements: Breathing movements are part of the complete Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which only uses NST and AFI.

 

Option D. NST and gross fetal movements: Gross fetal movements are part of the full Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which comprises only NST and AFI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI).

 

Ref: Page no 980, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.
